author: By Elena Bergeron
title: Is the Black Quarterback Revolution Going to Last?
description: Patrick Mahomes of the Kansas City Chiefs is part of a vanguard redefining the position. But it is a watershed only if it is widespread and persistent.
content: MIAMI — The N.F.L.’s longtime leading men, the ones with the pizza commercials and the Super Bowl rings, whose names adorn the league’s most-sold jerseys, showed their mortality this season in ways that were uncomfortable to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Ellis
title: President Trump recycles insults aimed at Democratic candidates.
description: Mr. Trump was interviewed by Sean Hannity during a Super Bowl pregame show.
content: The Super Bowl pregame show on Sunday afternoon included what has become a traditional feature for the broadcast: an interview with the president of the United States. This time, it afforded President Trump the opportunity to criticize Democrats vying to be his general election opponent — and offered a preview of what some of his insults might look like in a general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Elizabeth Warren goes back to basics: running against corruption.
description: In a pair of appearances on college campuses, Senator Elizabeth Warren remained laser-focused on a central theme of her candidacy.
content: AMES — In a pair of appearances on college campuses on her final full day of campaigning before the Iowa caucuses, Senator Elizabeth Warren remained laser-focused on a central theme of her candidacy: combating corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudio E. Cabrera
title: How Kobe Bryant Made Everyone, Including the Haters, Respect His Game
description: A sports fan who found Bryant difficult to root for during his basketball career grapples with the pain, and regret, he feels in the wake of his death.
content: I was in a CVS in Harlem when I first heard the news. My friend James, who rarely, if ever, talks about sports, had sent me a one-word text message: “Kobe?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: ‘Bad Boys’ Stays on Top of the Box Office in Its Third Weekend
description: “Gretel & Hansel” and “The Rhythm Section” failed to make a strong impression with audiences.
content: For “Bad Boys for Life,” the third weekend was the charm. Just like the second was. And the first.
source.name: The New York Times

title: He Assaulted His Girlfriend. Now He Wants a Political Comeback.
description: Hiram Monserrate, the first member of New York’s Legislature to be expelled in nearly a century, is running again.
content: For the better part of a decade, the name Hiram Monserrate has been shorthand for the darkest side of New York politics.

title: Coronavirus Pummels Wuhan, a City Short of Supplies and Overwhelmed
description: It is nearly impossible to get the care they need to treat, or even diagnose, the coronavirus, say residents at the crisis’ center.
content: WUHAN, China — Weak with fever, An Jianhua waited in line for seven hours outside the hospital in the cold, hoping to get tested for the new coronavirus, which doctors suspected she had contracted.

title: Confused about the four sets of Iowa results? We got you.

title: Review: Going Beyond Beethoven, by Playing Works in His Shadow
description: The American Symphony Orchestra, led by Leon Botstein and joined by the pianist Lucas Debargue, programmed Spohr, Ustvolskaya, Liszt and Reger.
content: The American Symphony Orchestra’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday had two claims on news. The first: a cheeky approach to the Beethoven-theme concerts that almost every ensemble seems to be planning this year to coincide with the 250th anniversary of his birth. (Cheeky, because — spoiler alert — no Beethoven works were on the program, titled “Beyond Beethoven.”) The second: the New York orchestral debut of Lucas Debargue, an exciting young French pianist.
source.name: The New York Times

content: DUBUQUE — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Sunday stressed the urgency of electing a president with experience on the world stage, emphasizing a core contrast he is making with his rivals on the eve of the Iowa caucuses.

description: As the overall death toll passed 360, a quarantine is being expanded in Wuhan, the central Chinese city where the coronavirus began.

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: How the Chiefs Beat the 49ers to Win the Super Bowl
description: Patrick Mahomes led the Chiefs to three fourth-quarter touchdowns as Kansas City won its first Super Bowl title in 50 years.
content: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — After a 50-year wait, the Kansas City Chiefs are Super Bowl champions once again, after Patrick Mahomes engineered a stirring fourth-quarter comeback Sunday to beat the San Francisco 49ers, 31-20, at a raucous Hard Rock Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Can Democrats Beat Trump in Iowa in November?
description: Iowa voted strongly for Barack Obama twice and for Donald Trump by nine points in 2016. It could be a national barometer again in November.
content: DES MOINES — For a full year, Democrats owned the Iowa spotlight as presidential candidates logged thousands of visits, spent tens of millions on TV and digital ads, and boasted of rallies that drew, on some of their best days, 1,000 ardent supporters hoping to defeat President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Matthew Abbott
title: Australia’s Volunteer Firefighters Are Heroes. But Are They Enough?
description: The country relies heavily on civilians to contain its fires, but the monstrous blazes that come with climate change threaten to break the system.
content: BATLOW, Australia — Most of the fires Michael Blenkins has put out since becoming a volunteer firefighter in the 1980s required little more than rushing to a nearby farm and hosing down ankle-high flames. In and out in maybe an hour, then back to work as a teacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘1917’ and ‘Parasite’ Are Big Winners at the BAFTAs
description: But the lack of diversity in the nominees dominated the award ceremony. It “cannot be right in this day and age,” Prince William, the British Academy’s president, said.
content: LONDON — “1917,” Sam Mendes’s visually extravagant World War I drama that takes viewers into the chaos of the trenches was the big winner at the EE British Academy Film Awards on Sunday, taking seven awards including best film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Review: HBO’s ‘McMillions’ Reminds Us That Every Era Has Its Scam
description: A six-part documentary tells the story of the great 20th-century McDonald’s Monopoly fraud case with quirky characters and lackluster visuals.
content: Oftentimes when listening to one of the dozens of excellent investigative podcasts I struggle to commit to, I’ll think, “this would make a great TV show.” When watching “McMillions,” a documentary series premiering on HBO Monday night, mostly I thought, “this would make a great podcast.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: Philippines Reports First Coronavirus Death Outside China
description: A 44-year-old man who traveled from Wuhan, China, the center of the outbreak, died in the Philippines, officials said.
content: HONG KONG — A 44-year-old man in the Philippines has died of the coronavirus, the first known fatality outside China, health officials said on Sunday, as the number of deaths jumped to more than 360 and other countries expanded travel restrictions in an effort to slow the spread of the outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: U.K. Police Kill Man in a ‘Terrorist Related’ Incident
description: The shooting occurred after people were stabbed in South London. The motive was unclear. The suspect had a fake explosive device strapped to his body.
content: LONDON — A man armed with a knife and wearing a fake explosive device strapped to his body was shot and killed by the police in South London on Sunday after he was suspected of stabbing people on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Merger With Christian University Stokes Uproar Over Faith and Free Expression
description: The union of Watkins College of Art and Belmont University in Nashville prompted concern that non-Christian faculty members could be purged.
content: Students at Watkins College of Art in Nashville describe it as an oasis in the Bible Belt, a small supportive campus welcoming to all and committed to free expression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Stand Here for Your Candidate: Iowans State Their Preferences in Public
description: Caucusgoers, uniquely, will declare their loyalty before their friends and neighbors. And they are taking their responsibility very seriously.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — It is a public display of civic duty unique in American politics: Iowans on Monday night will stand in front of their neighbors and express their preference for a candidate for president. No curtains covering a voting machine. No private paper ballots. Just a declaration of loyalty before fellow Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bernie Sanders and Vampire Weekend fill an arena.
description: Bernie Sanders closed out his night with a huge concert in Cedar Rapids, featuring Vampire Weekend.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — Bernie Sanders closed out his night with a huge concert in Cedar Rapids, featuring Vampire Weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Highly anticipated Iowa poll is canceled.
description: The survey is considered the gold standard for polling in the notoriously hard-to-predict state and is carefully watched as an early indicator of strength in the caucuses.
content: A highly anticipated poll of Iowa Democrats, set to be released two days before the presidential caucuses, was shelved on Saturday night after complaints about irregularities in the methodology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: Wuhan Coronavirus Looks Increasingly Like a Pandemic, Experts Say
description: Rapidly rising caseloads alarm researchers, who fear the virus may make its way across the globe. But scientists cannot yet predict how many deaths may result.
content: The Wuhan coronavirus spreading from China is now likely to become a pandemic that circles the globe, according to many of the world’s leading infectious disease experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Yang has a prediction on the scrapped Register poll.
description: He also recalled an argument Hillary Clinton made in 2016 that didn’t work out.
content: DES MOINES — Pacing the stage Saturday evening in an overflowing hotel ballroom in Des Moines, Andrew Yang reeled off a familiar array of facts and figures, including the decline of Americans’ life expectancy, the millions of trucking and retail jobs vulnerable to automation and the zero dollars Amazon pays in federal taxes. But it was an unknown data set that quickly stirred up his crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Woman Like Her: The Story Behind the Honor Killing of a Social Media Star,’ by Sanam Maher: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “A Woman Like Her: The Story Behind the Honor Killing of a Social Media Star,” by Sanam Maher
content: It takes a little over two hours to drive from Multan, a city in southern Punjab, to the village of Shah Sadar Din. After many checkpoints, where officers shake down the young men on motorbikes, some riding two or three at a time, their thin arms curled around each other’s waists, you’ll see a silty brown river snaking past men lounging on charpoys by its banks. On the way, if you admire the fields of sugarcane, each stalk taller than a man, your driver, a local who has played under the green sway of these plants as a child, will scoff. The ganna is short this year because there has been little water. He has seen these plants soar to fifteen feet. On the side of the road men and women stand by smoking steel vats, stirring a muddy treacle, folding crushed almonds and dried fruit into the soupy folds of the molasses. They sell packets of this liquid sugar along the highway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Even at smaller events, crowds show up for Sanders.
description: Bernie Sanders started his last day of campaigning in Iowa with something a little more sedate than a rally-concert.

title: Joe Biden: ‘Why don’t you let Joni Ernst know just how smart you are?’
description: The former vice president has highlighted two foils for his campaign in the final days before the caucuses: President Trump and Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa.
content: DUBUQUE — In the final week before the caucuses, Joseph R. Biden Jr., the former vice president, has highlighted two foils for his campaign: President Trump as well as Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, who had appeared to imply that the impeachment proceedings that put Mr. Biden’s family in the spotlight could damage him in the caucuses.

When Mr. Sanders was stuck in Washington for the impeachment trial, Ms. Sanders campaigned for her husband across the state, relaying his message at coffee shops and colleges.

title: Israel Puts Brakes on West Bank Annexation Plan
description: The Trump administration sought the delay, prompting fears among Netanyahu allies that it may cost them votes in the March election.
content: JERUSALEM — Shortly after last week’s rollout of the contentious American Middle East plan, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government made a triumphant promise that the cabinet would vote this weekend to extend Israeli sovereignty over substantial parts of the occupied West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: How to Watch Super Bowl 2020: Kickoff Time, Halftime and More
description: The San Francisco 49ers and the Kansas City Chiefs are ready to battle for N.F.L. supremacy in a matchup worthy of the spectacle attached to it.
content: [What we learned from Kansas City’s comeback win over the 49ers.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Quieter Response to Coronavirus in Countries Where China Holds Sway
description: Top officials in Southeast Asia have played down the threat of the virus and shied away from travel bans. Some have even pushed supposed remedies not supported by science.
content: BANGKOK — In Myanmar, loudspeakers broadcast advice from Buddhist monks: Seven ground peppercorns, exactly seven, placed on the tongue will ward off the coronavirus spreading across Asia and the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Let us help you start your day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey, Alan Rappeport, Trip Gabriel and Robert Gebeloff
title: The Graying of the American Economy Is On Display in Iowa
description: The state with a huge influence in picking presidential candidates doesn’t look much like the country as a whole. Except in the 60-plus crowd.
content: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Like most campaign events held in daylight hours during the week, Pete Buttigieg’s town hall in Dubuque recently was a sea of gray hair. When the time came for questions, many were from older people sharing personal stories of declining health, concerns about the cost of prescription drugs and questions about access to experimental treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: CNN cancels show after Buttigieg campaign complains that new poll excluded candidate in at least one call.
description: An Iowa supporter of Pete Buttigieg received a poll phone call but Mr. Buttigieg’s name was not listed on the menu of candidate options.
content: DES MOINES — CNN abruptly canceled a special Saturday night broadcast of the results of a new Des Moines Register poll of Iowa caucusgoers, according to a network official, after complaints from Pete Buttigieg’s campaign that his name was not included in at least one of their telephone calls for its poll this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Erica Roseman, Adam Perlmutter
description: The couple met on JDate and were married in Brooklyn.
content: Erica Jane Roseman and Adam David Perlmutter are to be married Feb. 2 at the Greenpoint Shul, Congregation Ahavas Israel, in Brooklyn. Rabbi Maurice Appelbaum is to officiate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chelsea Sullivan, John Leddy
description: The couple met in Hartford, Conn., at Trinity College, from which they graduated.
content: Chelsea Virginia Sullivan and John Colin Leddy were married Feb. 1 at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Olivia Whitney, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Masked Singer’ and the Super Bowl
description: On Fox, a bizarre competition series returns, and Jennifer Lopez and Shakira perform in the halftime show.
content: THE MASKED SINGER 10:30 p.m. on Fox. You may ask yourself two questions while watching this vocal competition: Who’s behind the mask, and how can they breathe in that thing? The series, back for Season 3, has celebrities compete against one another by belting out pop songs while decked out in elaborate disguises. The contestants’ identities are only revealed after they are voted off the show. (Previous singers include a shimmering butterfly and a fox in a top hat.) Nick Cannon returns as host, joined by the panelists Ken Jeong, Jenny McCarthy, Nicole Scherzinger and Robin Thicke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The last major poll of the Iowa caucuses comes out tonight.
description: Amid the campaigning and the schmoozing, the baby-kissing and hand-shaking, the political world prepared for a big arrival in Iowa on Saturday night.
content: DES MOINES — Amid the campaigning and the schmoozing, the baby-kissing and hand-shaking, the political world prepared for a big arrival in Iowa on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: CNN cancels show after Buttigieg campaign complains that new poll excluded candidate in at least one call.
description: An Iowa supporter of Pete Buttigieg received a poll phone call but Mr. Buttigieg’s name was not listed on the menu of candidate options.
content: DES MOINES — CNN abruptly canceled a special Saturday night broadcast of the results of a new Des Moines Register poll of Iowa caucusgoers, according to a network official, after complaints from Pete Buttigieg’s campaign that his name was not included in at least one of their telephone calls for its poll this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
title: Trump Campaign and R.N.C. Spent $9 Million in 4th Quarter, Mostly on Digital Ads
description: The groups supporting the president’s re-election bid also made 150 payments to Trump-owned entities and properties, Federal Election Commission filings show.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s campaign and the Republican National Committee together spent more than $9 million on polling, digital ads and fees paid to Trump-owned properties in the last three months of 2019, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura M. Holson
title: Does Your Pet Really Need Cat TV or a Dog Playlist?
description: Streaming services like Amazon Prime and Spotify offer videos, playlists and narrated books to entertain dogs and cats. But who loves it more: The pets? Or their owners?
content: This is a story about Opie and Karma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: One day to go.
description: It’s the last full day of campaigning in Iowa, and we’ll bring you live updates from around the state.
content: DES MOINES — Welcome to the last full day of campaigning before the Iowa caucuses. We have reporters on the ground all over the state and will bring you live updates throughout the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Warren, Sanders and Klobuchar will return to the Capitol on Iowa caucus day.
description: The senators will return to Washington on Monday, taking them off the campaign trail in Iowa in the final hours before the caucuses.
content: INDIANOLA — Senators Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders and Amy Klobuchar will return to Washington on Monday for the Senate’s continuing impeachment trial of President Trump, taking them off the campaign trail in Iowa in the final hours before the caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Sanders leads 2020 rivals in donors from Iowa.
description: More than 12,600 people in Iowa donated to Senator Bernie Sanders’s presidential campaign through the end of 2019.
content: DES MOINES — More than 12,600 people in Iowa donated to Senator Bernie Sanders’s presidential campaign through the end of 2019, giving him the largest number of donors in the state among the Democratic candidates, according to an analysis of fund-raising records filed with the Federal Election Commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Warren has a plan for skipping her ‘selfie’ line: her dog.
description: Elizabeth Warren has had to skip taking photos with everyone who wants one at her events.
content: INDIANOLA — It has become a symbol and signature of Senator Elizabeth Warren’s populist candidacy. She has called it a staple of democracy. But in these final frenetic days ahead of the Iowa caucuses, Ms. Warren is no longer staying for a personal picture with every single person who comes to her events and wants one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden aims for surrogate show of force.
description: A host of prominent surrogates pitched Mr. Biden as an experienced and empathetic leader who could defeat President Trump and aid Democrats running in competitive races.
content: DES MOINES — A host of prominent surrogates spoke at the start of former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s final event of the day, pitching him as an experienced and empathetic leader who could defeat President Trump and aid Democrats running in competitive down-ballot races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By K.K. Rebecca Lai, Josh Katz, Rachel Shorey, Thomas Kaplan and Derek Watkins
title: The Donors Powering the Campaign of Bernie Sanders
description: These maps and charts show just how much Mr. Sanders is prevailing in the race for donors.
content: These maps and charts show just how much Mr. Sanders is prevailing in the race for donors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Preacher Arrested After Tanzania Church Stampede Kills at Least 20
description: A dozen others were injured during a church meeting in the northern city of Moshi, the government said.
content: DODOMA, Tanzania — Twenty people were killed and a dozen others injured in a stampede during a church meeting in the northern Tanzanian city of Moshi, the government said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Like Its 2 Royal Guests, Canada’s Most English City Reinvents Itself
description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, have retreated from royal life to Victoria, which has long embraced its queenly name. But the city, like the duke and duchess, is breaking with tradition.
content: VICTORIA, British Columbia — If Prince Harry ever gets lonesome for royal life while in Canada, he can always visit his great-great-great-great-grandmother, perched at a dining room table over a glass of sherry, her hair lovingly shampooed and fluffed by one of her most devoted subjects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Imagines the Impeachment Trial That Could Have Been
description: On Super Bowl weekend, Alec Baldwin returned to play President Trump in an episode that also featured several football-themed sketches.
content: If you ended the week hoping that President Trump’s impeachment trial would go on longer, this weekend’s opening “Saturday Night Live” sketch imagined just such a scenario: a parade of self-serving witnesses that wasn’t necessarily an improvement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld and Jim Rutenberg
title: Jeff Bezos Is Sued by His Girlfriend’s Brother
description: Michael Sanchez says he was trying to protect his sister in a lawsuit complaint.
content: The brother of Jeff Bezos’s girlfriend has filed a lawsuit accusing Mr. Bezos and his security consultant of defaming him in connection with a 2019 National Enquirer story revealing Mr. Bezos’s extramarital affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Lin, Thomas Fuller and Richard Fausset
title: ‘Scared and Panicked’: Travelers Rush to Avoid Virus Quarantine
description: American officials issued a cutoff of 5 p.m. on Sunday for airline passengers to leave China before being denied entry to the United States or subject to two-week quarantine.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Amid canceled flights, tightening global travel restrictions and looming plans to quarantine Americans returning from China, the tension at a handful of airports still receiving flights from the country mounted on Sunday as travelers described a scramble for the few remaining tickets out of China and federal officials readied military bases to house hundreds of people potentially exposed to the deadly coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Al Qaeda Claims It Directed Florida Naval Base Shooting
description: In an audiotape message, Al Qaeda’s leader in Yemen claimed responsibility for the December attack that killed three U.S. sailors. The militant himself was most likely killed in a drone strike after he made the tape.
content: CAIRO — Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula claimed on Sunday that it directed a Saudi military officer to carry out the shooting at a United States military base in Florida in December that killed three sailors and wounded eight people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle and Andrea Salcedo
title: Suicide at Hudson Yards Vessel: Teenager Jumps Over Railing
description: The death on Saturday night stunned onlookers who were visiting the 150-foot-high steel structure.
content: A 19-year-old man jumped to his death on Saturday from the Vessel, the sculpture that is the centerpiece in the Hudson Yards development, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Novak Djokovic Wins Australian Open, Tightens Grand Slam Race
description: The victory over Dominic Thiem in five sets gave Djokovic his 17th Grand Slam singles title, and allowed him to reclaim the No. 1 ranking.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was a highly unusual Australian Open, beginning with the prologue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Tomasky
title: It’s 2020. Time for Democrats to Ignore These Two States.
description: Everybody talks about Iowa and New Hampshire, but nobody does anything about it. Here’s an idea.
content: Iowa and New Hampshire. Here they come again, reliably in grim tandem, like the flu and gastroenteritis. Two small, unrepresentative states will set the terms of the Democratic presidential campaign, exerting far more influence over the nominating process than states that rank 32nd and 42nd in population have any right to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Republicans’ Emerging Defense: Trump’s Actions Were Bad, but Not Impeachable
description: A growing number of Republicans have acknowledged that President Trump’s phone call with Ukraine wasn’t perfect. But they argue that it doesn’t merit his removal.
content: WASHINGTON — Even as they are set to acquit President Trump in his impeachment trial this week, Senate Republicans appear to be increasingly breaking with his defense that he did nothing wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: 2020 Super Bowl Commercials: Funeral for Mr. Peanut, Tears for Google
description: Uplifting spots from major brands stayed away from divisive issues on TV’s biggest ad day. But Trump and Bloomberg crashed the party.
content: An audience expected to be around 100 million. Big companies paying as much as $5.6 million for 30 seconds of advertising time. In addition to deciding the National Football League champion, the Super Bowl is the biggest event of the year for TV commercials.
source.name: The New York Times
